title: Race hate speech review to call for change amid rising number of cases
text:
Race hate laws could be eased 0:46 
A parliamentary inquiry into the Racial Discrimination Act is set to deliver its recommendation. February 28th 2017 7 hours ago /video/video.news.com.au/News/ Australian Human Rights Commission Race Discrimination Commissioner Tim Soutphommasane has been accused of encouraging the number of complaints. Picture: Glenn Hunt Staff writers News Corp Australia Network Share Share on Twitter 
NINE white men are among a growing number of people lodging claims of racial discrimination with the Australian Human Rights Commission. 
Most of the 71 complaints lodged with the commission in the past year were from Aborigines and Indians but almost 15 per cent were white men, The Australian reports. 
Other complaints, where a race was identified, came from people identifying as Chinese, Maori, Persian, Scottish, Pakistani, Jewish, Arab, Turkish and one who had a “dark complexion”. Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull launched the review of the Racial Discrimination Act last year. Picture: Kym Smith Source: News Corp Australia 
There were just 18 complaints to the Commission in the 12 months to March 2016. 
A parliamentary committee will table a review of Section 18C of the Racial Discrimination Act today, which will also look at whether the complaints-handling procedures of the Commission should be reformed. 
Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull ordered the inquiry after pressure from his party over a string of cases last year, including complaints over a Bill Leak cartoon and university students’ Facebook posts. 
RELATED: Malcolm Turnbull promised 18C changes ahead of Tony Abbott spill 
The Australian reports one of the inquiry’s recommendations will be for the Turnbull Government to scrap the terms “insult and offence” and replace it with the tougher test of “vilify” or “harass”. Senator David Leyonhjelm last year lodged a formal complaint with the Human Rights Commission under race hate laws for being publicly labelled an “angry white male”. Picture: Gary Ramage Source: News Corp Australia 
The jump in racial discrimination complaints was revealed after a freedom-of-information request by Melbourne-based think tank the Institute of Public Affairs. 
IPA policy director Simon ­Breheny has blamed the rise in complaints on Human Rights Commissioner Tim Soutphommasane. 
“‘Commissioner’ is the perfect title for Tim Soutphommasane, who appears to spend all his time commissioning complaints under section 18C,” Mr Breheny told The Australian . 
“Soutphommasane’s incessant solicitation appears to have led to a massive increase in the number of complaints being handled by the Human Rights Commission.” 
Mr Breheny said a large number of submissions to the inquiry favouring no change to the race hate speech laws were from government agencies or taxpayer-funded groups. Deputy Opposition leader Tanya Plibersek says Labor will not support changes to section 18C of the Racial Discrimination Act. Picture: AAP Source: AAP 
“This is a sock-puppet arrangement where government departments give money to organis­ations to advance the anti-change argument,” he said. 
“This process can give the ­appearance of public support for changes when the reality is that Australians understand the damage caused by section 18C in cases like the one against the QUT ­students.’’ 
Deputy Opposition leader Tanya Plibersek told ABC radio the review was an “absolute sideshow” and Labor would not support changes to racial discrimination laws.
